text: thank you everyone for coming today as jeff mentioned this is my phd defense so i'll be presenting my thesis work
entitled insights from patient authored text from close reading to automated extraction and i'll start by answering
the question that is probably on everybody's mind what is patient author text and why do we care about it and
then i'll state the contributions of our work and describe our data and methodological process having
established these preliminaries i'll present our first project a depth in which we address the problem of
identifying medical terms in pad and i'll then spend the majority of my time talking about our work on forum 77
in which we focus specifically on pat related to the topic of substance abuse i'll go through three projects called
drugs of choice purpose and phases of addiction and finally i'll offer some concluding
thoughts present key areas for future work and take questions
so when the internet became commercially available in the mid 90s it revolutionized the way in which we
interact with health data firstly it made this information more available to people
it also promoted your ever your everyday health information consumer to a health information contributor and thirdly it
facilitated connections between people with shared interests and so using the internet as a health resource is
extremely popular and remains so was well has always been extremely popular and remains so today so in 2002
2012 the pew health online survey estimated that some 72 percent of american adults go online to seek health
information and that of these 17 16 to 18 percent of them specifically seek out
other people who share their health concerns now that might not sound like a lot but if we extrapolate from the census
bureau's population estimate for the united states this comprises some 50 to 57 million people and the result of this
is that users are online generating massive quantities of what we call patient authored text
which is essentially any medical text that's authored by a non-medical expert
a main source of patient author texts are online health communities which are just online discussion boards centered
around a particular medical topic probably everyone in this room has consumed data from an online health
community even if you've not contributed to one and this is the type of data we use in our work
other sources of pat include personal blogs email search logs and social media data such
as facebook and twitter so that's all well and good but what actually goes into creating pat
this here is a sample post from forum 77 that helps community for addiction this user is taping tapering off methadone
and he wants some advice on managing his withdrawal symptoms and at a glance we can tell that there's quite a bit of
information here there's a medical history there's a treatment plan
there's a detailed record of his symptoms including waves of depression bad thoughts anger finding it hard to
move and then there's a request for advice on a specific symptom that's troubling him
these are fairly typical components of pat others might include users performing drug comparisons
diagnoses or comparing medical test results
so overall in the process of creating pat users are documenting medical data they're making sense of it they're
prioritizing it they're synthesizing it and they're doing this in order to solve problems that are relevant to them
and this is time intensive work performed by highly motivated agents and together this work culminates in a
unique record of patients behavior outside of the clinical environment
this is especially true in the cases of embarrassing or stigmatized conditions such as hepatitis c or addiction because
prior work actually shows that such people are more likely to seek health information online and in some cases
less likely to seek formal medical attention so in concert pat comprises a valuable
and in many cases unique medical data set it's also abundant and readily available but in spite of this attempts
to leverage pat to gain medically relevant insights have been limited and there are a couple of reasons for this
the first is that while pat is rich with valuable data it's extremely noisy
at the text level we have misspellings inconsistent grammar at the user level
we have inconsistent participation we have data being filtered through a human who is only including the parts that she
thinks are relevant and this person has some unknown level of medical expertise and command over medical jargon
second there's the dearth of existing extracting tools extraction tools for analyzing pat so
for example as you'll see when i discuss adept it's difficult to even extract the medically relevant terms out of pat
this makes it hard to explore pat corporate let alone test hypotheses on them
and finally the question of whether pat actually supports a research question or not is not obvious and it depends very
deeply on the user's reason for authoring the text in the first place so for example it's been shown that search
logs are a good data set to try to mine to try to predict flu epidemic outbreaks
from because people are motivated to google for those their symptoms when they get sick however it would be
unlikely that we could mine the optimal dosage of paracetamol from twitter because people aren't posting on
twitter the dosage of paracetamol that they use so determining what data pad encodes and
how it's encoded is a separate challenge in and of itself in our work we address these challenges
in a couple of ways so to handle noisiness we obviously focus on entity resolution and text processing but at
the human level we leverage automated extraction to get large volumes of data this enables us to
aggregate over many people which can compensate for individual noisiness
to address the dearth of existing tools we follow a specific methodological framework that results in automatic
classifiers which we share to support future work and finally to address the question of
research support we both collaborated closely with an addiction specialist anna lemke
and utilized close readings over our source text in order to develop detailed schema describing the content of the
data we call these thematic analysis and this is actually a branch of prior work and
the goal of a thematic analysis is essentially to do a qualitative analysis over text to get a deep understanding of
its content and structure so for example murnanen counts analyze with the twitter feed of people who are
attempting smoking cessation in order to determine whether their behavior changes before and after the event it's rare
however to see thematic analyses leveraged to the point of automatic extraction
usually the data is hand labeled on the other end of the spectrum falls work on pharmacovigilance and syndromic
surveillance in which people mind pat in order to detect to detect adverse medical events in real
time so the example that people would be most familiar with is google flu where
uh the tool tries to predict flu outbreaks uh before they ahead of the cdc data
another category is entity extraction which falls under the purview of nlp and machine learning and this the goal in
here is to identify particular entities in text so for example in collaborative work with stoneal gupta and chris
we use flexible pattern matching to identify drugs and treatments and symptoms and conditions in med help text
and finally some prior work does combine thematic analysis with large-scale investigations most notably that by
mumunda chowdhury who analyzes postpartum depression as it manifests on users facebook and twitter feeds
now work on adept in drugs of choice falls closer to the entity extraction and syndromic surveillance side of
things and our work on phases of addiction and purpose built on prior work and literature from thematic analyses
automated extractions and large-scale analyses and we make two primary contributions
first we develop methods for automatically extracting a variety of medically relevant texts from data from
pat and second we derive novel insights from these extracted data what sorts of
insights well often they're medically relevant and they tell us something new about a condition we didn't know a lot about but they can also be used to
inform interface design or further hci or cscw
research and in this work we focus specifically on the topic of addiction for reasons i'll get into after i talk
about the adopt project we use data from the website med help which comprises about 200 online health
community communities each focused on a specific health topic and for the general med health data set
we have about three and a half years of discussion data and for our work on addiction we use
forum 77 which is med helps forum on addiction and substance abuse
this is the largest community on med health and we have seven years worth of discussion data comprised comprising
eighty thousand threads about three quarters of a million posts authored by some fifty thousand unique
users so just to get us on the same page about what these data actually look like
on the left here we have a number of names of online health communities each community dedicated to a specific
medical topic if you look inside a community you'll see that it's composed of a collection of threads or
discussions and if you looked into a discussion you would see that it's comprised of an
initiating post in which a user poses a question or a comment to the community and a
collection of response posts in which other people respond to the initiator and note that the initiator can also
respond to the thread later on we call this a self-response and so we'll use these terms initiating post
self-response and response posts towards the end of the talk in our work on phase
and what do we do with this data we use a similar methodological framework throughout our work starting
with patient author text a close reading gives insight into what kind of data pat encodes and how it encodes it this gives
us a schema over the content now sometimes the schema can just be internalized knowledge and sometimes the
schema is a contribution in and of itself if it's illuminating a poorly understood area
once we have a schema over the content we can use it to acquire human annotated data depending on the complexity of the
schema this might be an iterative stage in which we use our human labels to revise the schema
but once we're satisfied with our data annotation we then use it to train statistical classifiers to automatically
label large quantities of data again this can be an iterative process where we tune our classifier where we
tune out features in order to improve classifier performance once we're satisfied we can then apply
our classifiers to large quantity of pat to get machine labeled data and then after any required
post-processing we analyze the extracted data in order to derive insights
so i'm now going to present our work on adept
this work was motivated by what seemed to be a simple problem to us when we set out
given some patient author text like this how do we extract the terms that are medically relevant for example how do we
go from this text to this where we've highlighted the terms that are medically relevant in
green like many before us we turn to the most obvious solutions which are well-known
ontology-based tools meta-map and the open biomedical annotator ontologies are curated collections of vocabularies with
hierarchical relationships between the terms so using these tools gives you very nice
entity resolution unfortunately however they perform very poorly on pat and it's not just us who found this
the next obvious solution is to turn to a statistical based tagger and train a classifier
to specifically extract entities relevant to your task now these models have very good performance
but can require large volumes of training data this can be a problem especially when you need medical experts
to annotate your data because that's both costly and time-consuming however
given that our data is authored by non-medical experts in the first place we hypothesized that we might be able to
crowdsource this task so we post two hypotheses in this work first that a crowd can
that a crowd of non-experts can replace medical experts at the pat medical term identification task and second the
classifiers trained on this data would outperform the state-of-the-art tools meta map and oba
so to test our first hypothesis we first needed to design a crowdsourcing task and our original prompt which we ran
through amazon mechanical turk was to just copy paste terms that you find medically relevant into the text box
below and we got some pretty bad results the biggest problem was context so
users would include terms that could be medically relevant in some context but weren't in the sentence so in this
sentence anxiety is not a user symptom she's talking about a social phenomenon about talking to other people on the
forum a mission people just wouldn't do the task numerical inclusion and concept
granularity were very inconsistent so some people would include drug dosages some people would include the term low
in low blood sugar and others wouldn't and then repetition users would typically tag only one instance of a
word in a sentence even if it appeared multiple times so we found that changing the prompt to
ask users to include terms that they found that they thought a doctor would find medically relevant actually helped
the problem of context a great deal we think this is because it made the task seem less subjective than it actually
was we tried to address the issue of omission by getting them to put n a into
the text box anyway but this is still easier than copy pasting the terms this didn't help much however
when we told the turkers that we would reject their answers if they didn't match other turker's answers uh they
stopped admitting they stopped emitting things and the results became quite consistent
we dealt with numerical inclusion and concept granularity through explicit examples and repetition through
post-processing simply propagating the label of medically relevant to all other identical terms in the sentence
so having designed this task we next wanted to test the crowd's performance against medical experts we
took a sample of a thousand sentences from rent from midhelp and created a gold standard by getting
three registered nurses to label each sentence we took majority vote for turkey for token inclusion
and then had five turkers label each sentence and compared their performance across different voting thresholds to
the nurses we found that turkish perform well against the gold standard when we use a
corroborative voting policy which requires at least two terms to be to two
votes for a term to be labeled as medically relevant and so we conclude that a crowd of medical experts is a
sufficient replacement um for for medical experts in the pat term identification task
next we train a classifier that we call adept to automatically identify medically relevant terms
we choose adept to be a conditional random field model or crf because crfs are especially appropriate for
sequence-based and context-sensitive tasks basically given an item in a sequence a
crf can take into consideration the items that appear before and after that item in order to determine whether it
belongs to a specific entity class or not for example in these two sentences the word tired
occurs in both sentences but in the first one it's not a symptom whereas in the second one it is
a context-sensitive model is able to determine that the first sentence that the first instance of tired is not is
not medically relevant while the second one is and this is actually our classifier output by the way
we train adept on 10 000 crowd labeled sentences and then evaluate its performance
so performance on cross validation is good and holds to the gold standard which was labeled by the by the nurses
and then we also compare it against an independent gold standard which we source from cure together
which is a different online health community and again the adept performance holds
over this data set and also notable is the fact that it dramatically outperforms the other tools meta map
and the oba so we can see how a depth performs on
our original prompt green are the terms that it got correct it incorrectly
omitted night sweats night in the term night sweats and nightmares and it included some terms erroneously such as
sleeping and food but this last instance actually starts to highlight the ambiguity of
this task food in this case could be used as a treatment for this guy's withdrawal symptoms to make him feel
better we can look at adept's mistakes more generally to get insight into what it's
getting wrong and right so this chart logs term frequency against classification accuracy in our corpus
and blue dots show terms that were misclassified at least once the size of the dot represents the number of terms
so for example this bottom left-hand blue dot here shows that about 500 terms
were never correctly classified and these appeared only once in the test corpus
so unsurprisingly we see that items that occur less frequently are more likely to be incorrectly classified
so we might ameliorate some of these problems by adding additional training data and it remains to look at the terms that
are commonly or ambiguously classified in looking at these no obvious patterns
emerge save from the exception that a lot of them were what we call generic terms so terms like doctor doctors
appointment these are all terms that are definitely medical but they contain very little information and it turns out that
human annotators struggle with whether they should include these sorts of terms as well
so we show that a crowd of non-experts can replace medical experts at this task and this gets us cheap and scalable data
annotation but can we apply this to other sorts of entities
so we explored this in two projects we tried we tried to use a similar prompts to get turkish to identify drugs and
treatments in the same sort of text and also symptoms or conditions in the same sort of texts
and we got extremely poor results they were inconsistent and they were incorrect and sometimes the turkers
actually defaulted to just including any medically relevant term at all
we thought about why this was and the task is actually quite different from the adept task it's a lot more
subjective so for example the term wheelchair that's medically relevant but is it a treatment
and there's also this sort of scoping issue so symptom descriptions tend to span long phrases so a sharp pain on the
left side of my back spreading down to my thigh should you include that entire phrase as a symptom or should you break
it down into smaller components so it turned out that this is quite a different task and
could we actually crowdsource this well probably i think so but we would need to design the task specifically and it
became apparent that there's a trade-off between the cost of designing this task and the cost of just labeling the data
ourselves in our future projects we don't have we don't deal with big enough data sets
that we couldn't without we can't label it ourselves but this remains an important area for future work especially when you need
large quantities of label data or when you need to rapidly replicate your data annotation
so our crowdsourcing method gives us cheap and scalable data but there's a trade-off between designing the task and
labeling the data ourselves and finally our classifiers trained on the crowd label data did outperform state of the
state-of-the-art tools quite dramatically i won't go into the applications of
adept in the interest of time but if you apply adept to a pat corpus what you get is several medically relevant terms you
can do frequency and co-occurrence analyses over these terms to get a bird's-eye view over the over the
corpus's content as well as the structure within it
in the case of adept our close reading and content schema involved the iterative design of a crowdsourcing task for medical term
annotation we found that the crowd can indeed be used to annotate these data and that we
were able to train a conditional random field classifier on this crowd label data to outperform existing tools
finally we can apply the classifier to get a quick overview of a pat corpus
next i'm going to move on to our work on forum 77 but before i talk about our first project drugs of choice i'm going
to give a brief inter overview of why we want to look at addiction in the first place so why addiction
well drug and alcohol use disorders present one of the most pressing public health issues of the day and of
particular concern is the escalating misuse of prescription drugs so in 2008 more than 36 000 deaths
were due to overdoses of prescription drugs sorry were due to drug overdoses and of these those due to prescription
drugs accounted for more than those caused by heroin and concave and cocaine combined
in addition addiction is an extremely stigmatized medical condition so even within the
medical community the opinion that opioid misuse is a flaw
in a person's moral character is quite prevalent despite the fact that research recent evidence shows that it behaves
like a chronic and remitting disease perhaps unsurprisingly then people are
turning on mass online for help with addiction so forum 77 second from the
bottom here is our data set and it's the largest community on med health which says something in and of
itself we have about three quarter of a million posts here but as you can see even larger communities exist online
and these are just quick summary statistics that we gathered by hand this is not an exhaustive list
i'm going to give a quick overview of the important points of addiction that are that are useful for our work going
forward so what are prescription opioids i'm sure everyone's heard of oxycodone vicodin hydrocodone these are
painkillers they're very effective and they're also highly addictive
a subclass of these are called opioid replacement therapy opioids methadone suboxone and buprenorphine they're also
prescription opioids meaning they're also painkillers and they're also addictive however they're longer lasting
and they're less euphoric meaning that they're sometimes administered under the supervision of a medical expert
as a replacement therapy for a more addictive drug so what happens when you stop taking
opioids you go through withdrawal which is quite a painful process it's
compared to severe influenza and the duration of withdrawal depends on the drug that the user is taking the dosage
of the drug physiological factors but in the literature measures it to be approximately 7 to 10 days if you go
cold turkey which means you stop taking all your drugs or 20 to 35 days in the case of a taper which means you take
smaller and smaller doses of the drug until you stop taking it and so when does somebody recover well
the term recovery is very contentious there is a lack of agreement within the medical profession
as to whether you actually recover from addiction or not and this view is held over in groups like alcoholics anonymous
and narcotics anonymous instead it's thought that you're always recovering so we use the term recovering in our work
and finally relapse the use of drugs after withdrawing or recovering is common estimated to happen in some 81 to
91 percent of users so i'll now talk about drugs of choice
in which we try to identify what substances people on forum 77 are using why analyze this
well it helps us to contextualize the forum so there are many surveys of drug using populations out there but they're
almost all executed at point-of-care facilities such as emergency room departments or rehabilitation facilities
forum 77 participation is voluntary so if we find congruence in our population
with these other surveys we might be able to make epidemiological conclusions and if we don't we may find that we have
a population here that's currently flying under the radar there are also some useful applications
out of being able to identify drugs of choice we may be able to monitor the
the popularity of new designer drugs as they come out on the market we could also test theories on addiction
such as the gateway hypothesis which posits the drug use starts with less addictive drugs like marijuana and
alcohol and moves on to more harder and illicit substances like
cocaine and there are potential interface improvements for example we might be
able to match users who have the same drug of choice privacy considerations of course
so a drug of choice is any substance that the user indicates she was or is addicted to and this is again a
context-sensitive problem so in this sentence this user's drug of choice is suboxone because she's currently
tapering off it in this sentence the user's drug of choice is vicodin i'm quitting a 10-year
vik habit suboxone is being used as a replacement treatment later on if this user were to return to the forum and
start tapering off suboxone then suboxone would also become a drug of choice
and these are usually mentioned in people's initiating posts so to automate the extraction of drugs
of choice we follow a process similar to the one that we adopted in adept except that we label the data ourselves instead
of crowdsourcing the labeling and again a crf classifier trained on our label data does well at identifying drugs of
choice mentioned in initiating posts applying our classifier to the entire forum 777 data set then
allows us to derive the drug of choice distribution over the population we compare this to other prevalent
surveys on substance use and what we find is that forum 77 is distinct from
typically surveyed populations in terms of abuse substances so these users are
predominantly struggling with prescription opioid abuse however the more traditionally abused substances
alcohol marijuana and cocaine which are the three most prevalent substances on the other forums are quite absent in our
community we can also look at drug trends on the
forum over time and for simplicity we only show the six most popular opioids here we see these top two lines
hydrocodone and oxycodone decline slightly over time and it appears that suboxone and methadone our replacement
treatment opioids the pink and yellow lines here may increase a little bit
to make it easier to see we can combine these together so now the orange line represents opioid replacement
therapy opioids the green line represents all other opioids and heroin is the purple line on the bottom
so there is a slight decrease in the use of our other prescription opioids and a slight increase in your t opioids now
we'd have to do a lot more work to tie these to actual trends in the real population but
there are correlations or corroborations for example samsa's nsats report which
looks at methadone and buprenorphine prescriptions has cited a steady increase in buprenorphine prescription
issuing since about 2008 and recent work finds that as prescription opioids like oxycodone
become harder to tamper with and acquire on the black market people switch over to heroin
because it's actually easier to acquire
to summarize in reading this data we discover that about half of initiating posts mention
drugs of choice and we can use hand annotated data to train a conditional random field
classifier to identify these automatically finally applying our classifier to our entire data set we
find that our population is very distinct from other survey drug using populations and there's a possibility
that it reflects real world substance use trends next we move on to the topic of purpose
in which we address the question of why people participate in forum 77
and why might we want to do this this gives us insight into how forum 77
actually supports his users so prior work does show that emotional and informational support seeking drive
online health community participation however we want to go beyond this what kind of
support and how is this specific to the topic of addiction in addition to understanding users
motivations for participation uh the answering this question will help us drive future analyses as we said you
really need to understand why people are authoring this text in order to leverage it to get insights
and there are some compelling potential applications such as highlighting deficiencies in traditional treatment
options so what are people compensating for on the forum and exposing key areas for interface improvement
to investigate users reasons for initiating posts we first conduct a thematic analysis over a sample of
initiating posts and i'll quickly go through the process that we used so based on our existing knowledge of the
data set we first derived a schema that we felt appropriately described it
we then consulted with an addiction specialist and took a sample of data from our data
set split it between two annotators and then compared the overlapping labels in an
error analysis based on the results we refined our schema and repeated this
process until we arrived at a schema that produced consistent labels
congruent with prior work we did find that emotional and that informational and emotional support
seeking do drive participation on forum 77.
with informational support seeking however the majority of content regards the
topic of withdrawal it's actually quite unusual to find an informational request that does not deal with withdrawal
and in the emotional category we had a surprise so we did find support seeking and support
giving which is what we expected but the most prevalent label in this category and actually in the entire schema is
this thing called the update post and what is an update post an update
post is exactly what it sounds like it's a log-like report of the user's current status and it makes no explicit request
for feedback this is a pretty typical example of an update post i was used to taking eight to ten oxycodones a day i
haven't taken any of them since friday but i took one oxy 40 milligrams saturday and one on sunday morning it's
been almost 24 hours not too bad so far but i'm sure there's more to come
so given the prevalence of update posts we were able to tr to train two classifiers our first a logistic
regression classifier distinguishes informational from emotional posts and our second distinguishes update from
non-update posts then of course we analyze the result of applying these classifiers to the
entirety of our data set we analyze a number of features including thread lifespan which is the
number of days between the day when it was created and the last post
one of the first things we discover is that informational threads have longer life spans but fewer respondents
so why is this well a casual analysis suggests that what happens is that these
threads are easily recycled recycled by other users so newer users will come and
read through posts on the forum and they'll find a thread that relates to them they'll then reply to it in order to
revive it it may be that users feel that they're capitalizing on the work that others have already done in terms of explaining
a condition or set of symptoms in terms of gathering information or in terms of cultivating a collection
of people who already care about this issue so it may be that this is user's way of not reinventing the wheel
and while examining informational posts we stumbled upon an informational artifact on forum 77 called thomas's
recipe which turned out to give some interesting insight into the nature of information generation and sharing on
the forum so thomas's recipe is a detailed schedule for medication-managed opioid
withdrawal and it actually originated on med help around 2000 and it's extremely prevalent
on the forum it's very popular and it's gone beyond med help if you google it you'll get adwords sponsors for vitamin
supplements to help with opioid withdrawals so here's an example of thomas's recipe
from 2000 and i don't put this up here for you to read but to compare structurally to the version that was
posted in 2006 there are quite a lot of changes
number one we have a much longer disclaimer in the new version number two the ingredient list has
become substantially more organized it's even enumerated number three the instructions have
become much more detailed and if you actually read through them they've become more more applicable to a general
audience so in the 2000 version the recommended dosage of l-tyrosine is 4 000 milligrams
in the 2006 version it's recommended that you start with two thousand milligrams and then adjust accordingly
so why is this interesting it's interesting because these changes do not evidence a single person tweaking
a recipe they demonstrate a collaborative influence of a larger community and so form 77 is more than an
information repository some users at least actually use it to collaborate on
treatments that are effective and it is effective we checked with our addiction specialist she said this is pretty much
what she would recommend to a patient but that she hadn't thought of the l-tyrosine and that that was maybe a good idea
our other classifier is able to distinguish update from non-update posts an analysis of the output shows that
update posts actually have much shorter life spans but slightly more responses than other posts so
the fact that they get similar levels of responses is interesting because there's no explicit request for feedback this
implies that this request is implicit and expected but the shorter lifespan of the update
post ties into another result which is that the time that it elapses between success
between successive update posts is quite short so this shows the transition graph between the update state and a
non-update state here we see that consecutive update posts have on average four and a half
days between them which is certainly the shortest time elapsed between any two phases
so one explanation is that when users start posting updates they do so in quick succession posting the next one
kills the lifespan of the old one and taken together it's possible that in many cases
issuing update posts is a mechanism of maintaining momentum and community support during detoxification attempts
but possibly the most interesting thing about updates is their prevalence this indicates that users derive high utility
out of issuing update posts so what are people valuing here so
anecdotally we think that one thing that users value is simply being witnessed
right um this could be a self-enforcement mechanism to stay on a withdrawal
schedule or to prevent relapse but we do see users exhibiting a great deal of shame when they relapse and they don't
want to come back to the community before they've started another detox attempt but there's also a clear value
in documentation and we see users reflecting on their update posts in the
past so both for inspiration to progress if they've relapsed or as a way of generating a sense of self-efficacy if
they've successfully withdrawn they also use this as data so we've seen users go back and say well i checked my post and
last time it took me 19 days so maybe if i try this this time it'll take me 15
days to to detox other users also value people's update posts they read through them as a way of
getting a sense of what lies ahead so to summarize our close reading in
this case comprised of thematic analysis in which we elucidated categories describing users reasons for
participating in it in forum 77. congruent with prior work we found that emotional and informational support
seeking drive drive participation but we also found that most informational posts pertain
explicitly to the topic of withdrawal and that the most prevalent emotional post is the update
because the update post is so prevalent we're able to train two classifiers they distinguish emotional from informational
posts and update from non-update posts and through applying them we get some insight into what users value about
participating in the forum they also use it for collaborative treatment development they value having
an audience and they value it as a mechanism for public documentation
finally in our last project on forum 77 we investigate
the phase of addiction what do i mean by this so
everyone has heard of this thing called the cycle of abuse but what does it actually mean
it turns out that there is not a well-established definition or agreed upon cycle of abuse
right and moreover to the best of our knowledge there have been no attempts to quantify it we have no idea for example
how many times people relapse on average before achieving some sort of sustained recovery and
for example we don't know how long people tend to use for after they relapse before they try to quit again
so in this project we seek to define and quantity this and quantify the cycle of abuse as it manifests on forum 77 and
this gives us crucial insight into the role that forum 77 plays in the process of addiction recovery it's also as far
as we know the first attempt to quantify a cycle of abuse in any sort of data set
again we conduct a thematic analysis similar to our purpose project over-initiating posts in order to derive
a schema describing users phases for those familiar with the transtheoretic model of behavior change
i have the labels here on the left but i'm going to focus on the on the column form 77 label which is uh which are the
labels that emerged in our thematic analysis we can see that a variety of phases
manifest on forum 77 from use of substances to intention to quit to
planning to quit there's a lot of cessation attempts being able to tell whether users are
tapering or going cold turkey is a little more rare and then there are also a lot of users here who are currently
recovering now although this level of detail is
interesting these categories are too fine-grained for the computational models that we currently have so
accordingly we collapse them into three main classes using when someone is using drugs prior
to a cessation attempt withdrawing when someone is currently trying to quit
and recovering when someone has overcome the acute withdrawal symptoms and is no longer
detoxing from a substance now there were two things about this rubric that caused us to reconsider our
unit of analysis from the post to a sequence so the first is the low prevalence of
relapse labels here it turns out that while relapse is very very common users don't come to the forum and say guys i
relapse and i'm using again actually they're more likely to come back after they've started another cessation
attempt perhaps in an attempt to generate social capital again on the forum that they feel that they've lost
the other thing is the high prevalence of na posts these are posts for which we just can't tell what phase the user is
in that's not very useful so looking at sequences actually can
eliminate both of these cases so imagine that each circle here is a day
in a user's tenure and it's red if they're using on that day yellow if they're withdrawing green if

is methods for automatically extracting medically relevant data from pat
we explored crowdsourcing medical term annotation as an alternative to getting medical experts to annotate these terms
we found that this was feasible but not for all types of tasks and that there's a trade-off in task
design versus labeling the data yourself we leveraged thematic analyses to build
content schemas over more abstract or hidden data contained in pat and we show how these are both contributions in and
of them themselves for example describing the cycle of addiction and they're also useful as annotation
rubrics for hand labeling data building on the addiction literature we
employ a detailed feature analysis to determine how users behavior changes as they move through the phases of
addiction in the real world correlate with their behavior online and ultimately we were able to train
classifiers that automatically extract a variety of medically relevant data from pat including medical terms drugs of
choice the purpose of participation and the phase of addiction
our second contribution is insights derived from these extracted data as i mentioned these can be medically
relevant for example we found that forum 77 is distinct from other survey drug using populations this
means that studying it may actually reveal something interesting that we currently aren't able to observe through
existing surveys another interesting finding is that users actively collaborate on treatments
this might be an interesting application crowdsourcing treatment development
other insights stand as contributions relevant to the cscw and hci communities for example we found that users value
being witnessed and documenting their journey through the process of addiction but we also have compelling evidence
suggesting that participating in forum 77 plays an important role in aiding the withdrawal process
certain users are most likely to be recovering certainly users are most likely to be
recovering by the time that they leave although we do need to remember that our data are censored we don't know what happens to
them after they leave the forum however it may be helpful just to have a tool and to enhance a tool that will help you
withdraw successfully so in concert our contributions both underscore pat's latent value for
illuminating poorly understood or clandestine medical topics and offer viable methods that dramatically improve
our ability to realize this value

to share with other people and creating tools for these sorts of things would actually help to standardize the process

we could expose data driven withdrawal information so not only are people looking for this on the forum they read
